block.p: GERMANY: IRANIANS PROTEST Thousands of Iranians in exile demonstrated in Berlin against the start of a three-day state visit by President Mohammad Khatami. The police arrested scattered protesters after detaining dozens of opponents of the Tehran government during overnight searches of local residences. Security is high during Mr. Khatami's visit, the first by an Iranian leader since the 1979 Islamic revolution. Critics had urged Germany to withdraw the invitation because of Iran's poor rights record.

FRANCE: MORE MAD COW DISEASE Officials have found another three cases of mad cow disease, bringing the total this year to 26. The new outbreaks virtually assure that authorities will discover far more cases this year than they did last year, when 31 cases were recorded. Officials had hoped to see the number of cases declining by now. A testing program that started last month is likely to increase the number of cases even further, officials have warned.

RUSSIA: LATVIA ACCUSED Russia accused Latvia of ''blatantly inhuman'' behavior after a court ordered an 87-year-old Russian veteran imprisoned for two years for World War II crimes against humanity. The former Soviet K.G.B. official was convicted of persecuting dozens of people, nine of whom were condemned to death. Russia has long accused Latvia, its former satellite, of discriminating against ethnic Russians.

HONG KONG: ELITE VOTERS An elite group of voters elected 800 people, including Hong Kong's wealthiest man, Li Ka-shing, to be on a committee charged with selecting future lawmakers. Critics called the election undemocratic. Only 177,000 of Hong Kong's 3.1 million registered voters were eligible to choose the election committee, which will select six of the lawmakers for a 60-seat legislature, only 24 of whom will be popularly elected.

INDIA: CHURCH BLAST INQUIRY Surveillance and patrolling at all places of worship has been increased and a special team of detectives has been formed to investigate recent explosions in churches, said S. M. Krishna, chief minister of the southern state of Karnataka. A Bangalore church was hit by an explosion on Sunday, and in June bombs exploded in four churches in the states of Karnata, Andhra Pradesh and Goa.

TANZANIA: PLEA IN BOMBING The first defendant to stand trial in the 1998 bombings of American embassies in Dar es Salaam and Nairobi pleaded not guilty to a charge of conspiracy to murder by housing five men suspected in the attack. It was the first time that Rashidi Saleh Hemed had entered a plea since his arrest on Aug. 27, 1998, 20 days after a car bomb exploded at the Dar es Salaam blast, in which 11 people died. No trial date has been set.

GHANA: WOMEN PROTEST Women brought part of the capital of Accra to a standstill to protest the failure of the police and government to end a string of 25 unsolved murders of women over the last 18 months, two in the last two weeks. Hundreds of women abandoned offices and market stalls to join the protest. The women, wearing red arm- and head-bands, chanted war songs and blocked one of the city's main roads, bringing traffic to a halt.

IRAN: JEW SOUGHT AS SPY Tehran has issued an arrest warrant for an Iranian Jew, believed to be in the United States, who is accused of leading an Israeli spy ring, a judicial official said. Ten Jews said to be members of the ring were jailed on July 1. Hossein Ali Amiri, head of the judiciary in Shiraz, said the extradition of Eshaq Belanas would be sought on charges that he founded the ring. Mr. Amiri said Mr. Belanas fled Iran nine years ago.

SAUDI ARABIA: HIGH ROLE FOR PRINCESS A princess and distant cousin of King Fahd was named assistant under secretary at the Education Ministry, becoming the highest-ranking woman in the Saudi administration. The official news agency said the cabinet announced the appointment of Princess Al-Jawhara bint Fahd bin Mohammad bin Abdel Rahman al-Saud at the end of a meeting led by the king. Her post is in the department in charge of girls' education.

BRAZIL: ROYAL TRADE VISIT In an effort to build trade and cultural ties with Latin America's largest country, the only one that is not Spanish-speaking, King Juan Carlos I, left, and Queen Sofia of Spain have arrived for a weeklong visit that includes meetings with political and business leaders in four cities. Spain is now the second-largest foreign investor in such key sectors of the Brazilian economy as telecommunications and electrical power, exceeded only by the United States.

COLOMBIA: NEW FINANCE AIDE With the country mired in its worst economic crisis in a century, Juan Manuel Santos, a former trade minister under the opposition Liberal Party, has been named finance minister to replace Juan Camilo Restrepo, who resigned. Other cabinet changes are expected to follow as the embattled president, Andres Pastrana, tries to fashion a ''national unity'' government.

MEXICO: SUSPECT ARRESTED Police officers detained Agustin Vazquez Mendoza, accused by American authorities as the mastermind of the murder in Glendale, Ariz., of an undercover American drug agent, Richard Fass. In June 1994 Mr. Fass was killed by gunmen working for Mr. Vazquez during negotiations for the $160,000 purchase of 22 pounds of methamphetamine, according to a statement by the Drug Enforcement Administration. American authorities requested Mr. Vazquez's extradition.
